description: From Middle English liften, lyften, from Old Norse lypta (‚Äúto lift, air‚Äù, literally ‚Äúto raise in the air‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *luftijanƒÖ (‚Äúto raise in the air‚Äù), related to *luftuz (‚Äúroof, air‚Äù), perhaps from Proto-Indo-European *lewp- (‚Äúto peel, break off, damage‚Äù) or from a root meaning roof (see *luftuz). Cognate with Danish and Norwegian Bokm√•l l√∏fte (‚Äúto lift‚Äù), Norwegian Nynorsk and Swedish lyfta (‚Äúto lift‚Äù), German l√ºften (‚Äúto air, lift‚Äù), Old English lyft (‚Äúair‚Äù). See above. 1851 for the noun sense "a mechanical device for vertical transport".
(To steal): For this sense Cleasby suggests perhaps a relation to the root of Gothic êå∑êåªêåπêçÜêçÑêåøêçÉ (hliftus) "thief", cognate with Latin cleptus and Greek Œ∫ŒªŒ≠œÄœÑœâ (kl√©pt≈ç)).

entries.meaning: An act of lifting or raising.
The act of transporting someone in a vehicle; a ride; a trip.
(UK, Australia, New Zealand) Mechanical device for vertically transporting goods or people between floors in a building.
examples: Take the lift to the fourth floor.

entries.meaning: An upward force, such as the force that keeps aircraft aloft.
(measurement) The difference in elevation between the upper pool and lower pool of a waterway, separated by lock.
(historical slang) A thief.
examples: The lift came into the shop dressed like a country gentleman, but was careful not to have a cloak about him, so that the tradesman could see he had no opportunity to conceal any goods about his person.

entries.meaning: (dance) The lifting of a dance partner into the air.
Permanent construction with a built-in platform that is lifted vertically.
(figurative) An improvement in mood.
The amount or weight to be lifted.
examples: What's the maximum lift of this crane?

entries.meaning: The space or distance through which anything is lifted.
A rise; a degree of elevation.
examples: the lift of a lock in canals

entries.meaning: A liftgate.
(nautical) A rope leading from the masthead to the extremity of a yard below, and used for raising or supporting the end of the yard.
(engineering) One of the steps of a cone pulley.
(shoemaking) A layer of leather in the heel of a shoe.
(horology) That portion of the vibration of a balance during which the impulse is given.

verbs.description: lift (third-person singular simple present lifts, present participle lifting, simple past lifted or (rare, regional, obsolete) lift, past participle lifted or (rare, regional, obsolete) lift or (obsolete) yleft)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To raise or rise.
examples: The fog eventually lifted, leaving the streets clear.
You never lift a finger to help me!

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To steal.
examples: Kamal is out with twenty men to raise the Border side,And he has lifted the Colonel's mare that is the Colonel's pride.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To source directly without acknowledgement; to plagiarise.
(transitive, slang) To arrest (a person).
examples: Maybe the police lifted him and he's in Castlereagh [Interrogation Centre] because he'd been lifted three or four times previously and took to Castlereagh. They used to come in and raid the house and take him away.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove (a ban, restriction, etc.).
(transitive) To alleviate, to lighten (pressure, tension, stress, etc.)
(transitive) to cause to move upwards.
(informal, intransitive) To lift weights; to weight-lift.
examples: She lifts twice a week at the gym.

entries.meaning: To try to raise something; to exert the strength for raising or bearing.
examples: strained by lifting at a weight too heavy

entries.meaning: To elevate or improve in rank, condition, etc.; often with up.
examples: The Roman virtues lift up mortal man.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To bear; to support.
To collect, as moneys due; to raise.
(programming) To transform (a function) into a corresponding function in a different context.
(finance) To buy a security or other asset previously offered for sale.
(hunting, transitive) To take (hounds) off the existing scent and move them to another spot.
examples: I lifted the hounds (hoping to catch the leading ones there) to the far side of Hallaton Thorns.

description: From Middle English lifte, luft, lefte (‚Äúair, sky, heaven‚Äù), from Old English lyft (‚Äúatmosphere, air‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *luftu, from Proto-Germanic *luftuz (‚Äúroof, sky, air‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *lewp- (‚Äúto peel, break off, damage‚Äù).
Cognate with Old High German luft (‚Äúair‚Äù) (German Luft), Dutch lucht (‚Äúair‚Äù), Old Norse lopt, loft (‚Äúupper room, sky, air‚Äù). More at loft.

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal, chiefly Scotland) Air.
(UK dialectal, chiefly Scotland) The sky; the heavens; firmament; atmosphere.
examples: No, no, Leddy! the sun maun be up in the lift whan I venture to her den.
